1.1 Laplace’ Equation in Two Dimensions - Analytical

A long pipe runs parallel to the (z)-axis as shown in the figure. The sides are labeled with subscripts (l), (r), (t), (b) for the left, right, top, and bottom. These sites are held at potentials (V_l), (V_r), (V_t), and (V_b).

[[Image:long_pipe.png]]

In the following problem, you will be asked to verify the exact solution in Table 1.20 of the textbook.

In this problem, you will derive a general solution for the potential inside of the pipe, (\Phi(x,y)) that depends on (x_o), (y_o), (V_l), (V_r), (V_t), and (V_b).

I have sent a PDF of Chapter 3 of Griffiths to the Piazza email list, which covers problems related to this. In addition, I have [[Notes|notes]] that fill in the mathematical gaps in Griffiths’ examples.

  1. Assume only (V_l) is nonzero. Find the potential inside of the pipe and call it (\Phi_l(x,y)).

  2. Assume only (V_b) is nonzero. Find the potential inside of the pipe and call it (\Phi_b(x,y)). Finding this answer should be easy.

  3. Assume only (V_t) is nonzero. Find the potential inside of the pipe and call it (\Phi_t(x,y)).

  4. Assume only (V_r) is nonzero. Find the potential inside of the pipe and call it (\Phi_r(x,y)). Finding this answer should be easy.

Answer

The function

ψl​(x,y)=An​sin(nπy/y0​)sinh[nπ(x−x0​)/y0​]

satisfies (\nabla^2\psi=0) and three of the four boundary conditions. I’ve skipped the steps used in the notes to show this - after you’ve done the problem a few times, you can usually skip those steps and write down a function that satisfied Laplace’s equation and three of the four boundaries that are at zero potential. To satisfy the non-zero boundary condition, a Fourier sum is needed:

ψl​(x,y)=n=1∑∞​An​sin(nπy/y0​)sinh[nπ(x−x0​)/y0​]

Standard Fourier analysis gives

An​=−nπsinh(nπy0​/x0​)4V​n=1,3,… An​=0n=2,4,…

So the solution is

ψl​(x,y)=π4V​n=1,3,…∑∞​nsinh(nπy0​/x0​)sin(nπy/y0​)​sinh[nπ(x0​−x)/y0​]

The solution to the problem where only (\psi_r) is nonzero can be obtained by replacing (x) with (x_0-x) in the problem where only (\psi_l) is non-zero:

ψr​(x,y)=ψl​(x0​−x,y)=π4V​n=1,3,…∑∞​nsinh(nπy0​/x0​)sin(nπy/y0​)​sinh(nπx/y0​)

The solution to the problem where only (\psi_t) is nonzero can be obtained by swapping the coordinate labels in the problem where only (\psi_l) is non-zero:

ψt​(x,y)=π4V​n=1,3,…∑∞​nsinh(nπx0​/y0​)sin(nπx/x0​)​sinh[nπ(y0​−y)/x0​]

The solution to the problem where only (\psi_b) is nonzero can be obtained by replacing (y) with (y_0-y) in the problem where only (\psi_t) is non-zero:

ψb​(x,y)=π4V​n=1,3,…∑∞​nsinh(nπx0​/y0​)sin(nπx/x0​)​sinh(nπy/x0​) |}

Claim: The general solution for this problem is

Φ(x,y)=Φl​(x,y)+Φr​(x,y)+Φt​(x,y)+Φb​(x,y)

  1. Justify this claim.

Answer

The short answer is “superposition and uniqueness”. The associated explanation is that each of the individual potentials (\Phi_i) satisfy Laplace’s equation (\nabla^2\Phi_i=0), so their sum also satisfies Laplace’s equation, which follows from

∇2Φ=∇2(Φl​(x,y)+Φr​(x,y)+Φt​(x,y)+Φb​(x,y))=∇2Φl​(x,y)+∇2Φr​(x,y)+∇2Φt​(x,y)+∇2Φb​(x,y)=0

The sum of the solutions (\Phi) also satisfies the boundary conditions of the problem. Therefore, by uniqueness, the general solution is given by (\Phi).

  1. Can Gauss’ law be used in any way at any location to check your analytic answers derived above? If yes, provide details of your check. The textbook does not cover the fundamentals of Gauss’ law in great detail. As background reading, I suggest the Gauss’ law section of any upper-division E&M text for physicists or engineers.

Upload your solution to your GitHub account as HW2_1.pdf.

Answer

As covered in HW #1, to draw a field line, one computes the direction of the the field at a starting point and takes a small step in this direction. Because we don’t know the electric field at all points in the domain, one can do a bilinear interpolation using the four nearest points to the point where we want to know the electric field. |}

In the previous HW, you derived the relationship between the electric and magnetic fields for a monochromatic plane wave propagating in free space. In class, I derived the equations that related the electric and magnetic fields for the case where a plane wave propagating to the right encountered a change in either the permeability or permittivity (or both). The relationship between the electric fields in the two regions at the interface is E1​=E2​.

In region 1, the electric field is composed of a forward and backward propagating wave, E1​=E1+​+E1−​. In region 2, the electric field is composed only of a forward propagating wave, E2​=E2+​.

4 Multiple Impedances

In each of the kth segments (n=0,1,2) of the transmission line shown at [https://www.mathcha.io/editor/O4lYqspXSQqTP3ozGesgJy7BLHzgOmYjSZ2ez3V], the electric potential can be written in the form of a forward traveling voltage and a backward traveling voltage:

Vn​(z)=Vn+​e−jβn​z+Vn−​e+jβn​z

where the real potential is given by

Vn​(z,t)=Re[Vn​(z)ejωt]

Equivalently, the electric field in each dielectric region can be written in the form of a forward traveling electric field and a backward traveling electric field:

En​(z)=En+​e−jkn​z+En−​e+jkn​z

where the real field is given by

En​(z,t)=Re[En​(z)ejωt]

Assume that V0+​ is known. At z=0 and z=Δ, the potential and current must be continuous (the equivalent conditions for the dielectric problem are that E and H are continuous). Assume also that region 2 extends extends to infinity so V2−​=0.

Find V0−​(z), V1+​(z), V1−​(z), and V2+​(z).

Find V0−​(z)/V0+​(z) and V1−​(z)/V1+​(z).

Answer

In the following, I use x instead of z for the position coordinate. In addition, f​(x) means a complex function of the coordinate x and f​ means a complex constant. For example, a spatially dependent reflection coefficient will be defined as ρ​(x)=ρ​e+2jβx.

The general equation for potential as a function of x is

Vn​(x)=Vn+​e−jβn​x+Vn−​e+jβn​x

This can be rewritten as

Vn​(x)=Vn+​e−jβn​x(1+Vn+​Vn−​​e+2jβn​x)=Vn+​e−jβn​x(1+ρ​n​e+2jβn​x)=Vn+​e−jβn​x[1+ρ​n​(x)]

The general equation for current as a function of x is

In​(x)=Zn​1​(Vn+​e−jβn​x−Vn−​e+jβn​x)

which can be rewritten as

In​(x)=Zn​Vn+​​e−jβn​x(1−Vn+​Vn−​​e+2jβn​x)=Zn​Vn+​​e−jβn​x(1−ρ​n​e+2jβn​x)=Zn​Vn+​​e−jβn​x[1−ρ​n​(x)]

At the interface, xn,n+1​, between regions n and n+1, the potential and current are continuous:

Vn​(xn,n+1​)=Vn+1​(xn,n+1​)In​(xn,n+1​)=In+1​(xn,n+1​)

as so is the spatially dependent impedance defined by

Zn​(x)≡In​(x)Vn​(x)​=Zn​1−ρ​n​(x)1+ρ​n​(x)​

To simplify notation, set n=0. When complete, generality can be restored by replacing 0 with n and 1 with n+1. For n=0, the interface conditions are

V0​(x01​)=V1​(x01​)⇒V0+​e−jβ0​x01​[1+ρ​0​(x01​)]=V1+​e−jβ1​x01​[1+ρ​1​(x01​)]

I0​(x01​)=I1​(x01​)⇒Z0​V0+​​e−jβ0​x01​[1−ρ​0​(x01​)]=Z1+​V1+​​e−jβ1​x01​[1−ρ​1​(x01​)]

Taking the ratio of these two equations so as to eliminate V0+​ and V1+​ gives the equation for the continuity of Z(x) at the region 0/region 1 interface:

Z0​1−ρ​0​(x01​)1+ρ​0​(x01​)​=Z1​1−ρ​1​(x01​)1+ρ​1​(x01​)​

For the problem given, ρ​2​=0 because V2−​=0 was given. Incrementing the subscripts by 1 gives the equation for the continuity of Z(x) at the interface of regions 1 and 2:

Z1​1−ρ​1​(x12​)1+ρ​1​(x12​)​=Z2​1−ρ​2​(x12​)1+ρ​2​(x12​)​

With ρ​2​=0 and x12​=Δ, this is

Z1​1−ρ​1​(Δ)1+ρ​1​(Δ)​=Z2​

and so

ρ​1​(Δ)=Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​

Using the definition ρ​n​(x)≡ρ​n​e+2jβn​x,

ρ​1​e+2jβ1​Δ=Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​

and so the reflection coefficient for region 1 is:

ρ​1​=Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​e−2jβ1​Δ

To find the reflection coefficient ρ​0​, continuity of impedance can be used at the interface between regions 0 and 1:

Z0​1−ρ​0​(x01​)1+ρ​0​(x01​)​=Z1​1−ρ​1​(x01​)1+ρ​1​(x01​)​

With x01​=0, and using ρ​n​(0)=ρ​n​, this is

Z0​1−ρ​0​1+ρ​0​​=Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​

This is simplified if the spatially dependent impedance notation is used for the right-hand side

Z0​1−ρ​0​1+ρ​0​​=Z1​(0)

Solving for ρ​0​ gives

ρ​0​=Z1​(0)+Z0​Z1​(0)−Z0​​

Using Z1​(0)=Z1​[1+ρ​1​(0)]/[1−ρ​1​(0)]=Z1​(1+ρ​1​)/(1−ρ​1​) gives

ρ​0​=Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+Z0​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−Z0​​

In summary, the reflection ratios for all of the regions have been found given the reflection ratio in one region.

V1+​V1−​​=ρ​1​=Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​e−2jβ1​Δ⇒V1+​(x)V1−​(x)​=ρ​1​(x)=Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​e−2jβ1​(Δ−x)

V0+​V0−​​=ρ​0​=Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+Z0​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−Z0​​⇒V0+​(x)V0−​(x)​=ρ​0​(x)=Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+Z0​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−Z0​​e2jβ1​x

To find the values for the potentials given their ratios, go back to the continuity equation for potential at the first interface.

V1​(x01​)=V0​(x01​)⇒V1+​e−jβ1​x01​[1+ρ​1​(x01​)]=V0+​e−jβ0​x01​[1+ρ​0​(x01​)]

In this problem, V0+​ was given. Solving for V1+​ gives

V1+​=1+ρ​1​(x01​)1+ρ​0​(x01​)​V0+​e−j(β0​−β1​)x01​=1+ρ​1​1+ρ​0​​V0+​

The solution for V2+​ is found by incrementing the subscripts in this equation by 1.

V2+​=1+ρ​2​(x12​)1+ρ​1​(x12​)​V1+​e−j(β1​−β2​)x12​=[1+ρ​1​(Δ)]V1+​e−j(β1​−β2​)Δ

V0−​=ρ​0​V0+​=V0+​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+Z0​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−Z0​​

V1−​=ρ​1​V1+​=V0+​Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​e−2jβ1​Δ

V0+​(x)V0−​(x)​=ρ​0​(x)=Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+Z0​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−Z0​​e2jβ1​x

V1+​(x)V1−​(x)​=ρ​1​(x)=Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​e+2jβ1​(x−Δ)

V0−​(x)=V0+​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+Z0​Z1​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−Z0​​e+jβ1​x

V1−​(x)=V0+​Z2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​e2jβ1​(x−Δ)

V1+​(x)=V0+​1+ρ​1​1+ρ​0​​e−jβ1​x

V2+​(x)=V0+​1+ρ​1​1+ρ​0​​[1+ρ​1​(Δ)]e−j(β1​−β2​)Δe−jβ1​x

The general procedure followed above was

  1. Starting at the load interface xn−1,n​ where Zn​(xn−1,n​) is known because ρ​n​ is known, find all of the reflection coefficients by iteratively using the impedance continuity condition, which followed from the continuity of V(x) and I(x)

Zn−1​(xn−1,n​)=Zn​(xn−1,n​)

until n=1. Explicitly, the equation to be iterated can be found by solving

Zn−1​1−ρ​n−1​(xn−1,n​)1+ρ​n−1​(xn−1,n​)​=Zn​1−ρ​n​(xn−1,n​)1+ρ​n​(xn−1,n​)​

for ρ​n−1​

ρ​n−1​=e−2jβn−1​xn−1,n​Zn−1​Zn​​1−ρ​n​(xn−1,n​)1+ρ​n​(xn−1,n​)​+1Zn−1​Zn​​1−ρ​n​(xn−1,n​)1+ρ​n​(xn−1,n​)​−1​

  1. Starting at the interface between the first two regions (source region 0 and region 1), where V0+​ is known, iterate

Vn+1+​=Vn+​1+ρ​n+1​(xn,n+1​)1+ρ​n​(xn,n+1​)​e−j(βn​−βn+1​)xn,n+1​

A common requirement of power systems is that there is no reflected potential, which corresponds to V0−​=0 and ρ​0​=0. Given a fixed impedance for the source and load, and impedance and width of a region between the source and load can be adjusted to make V0−​=0. To do this, one needs to solve

ρ​0​=0=Z0​Z1​​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​+1Z0​Z1​​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−1​

which simplifies to

0=Z0​Z1​​1−ρ​1​1+ρ​1​​−1

Using

ρ​1​=e2jβ1​ΔZ2​+Z1​Z2​−Z1​​

and simplifying gives

e−2jβ1​ΔZ1​+Z2​Z2​−Z1​​=Z0​+Z1​Z0​−Z1​​

The two unknowns in this equation are Δ and Z1​ can be solved for by equating the real and imaginary parts. In the case where all of the impedances are real (corresponding to propagation with no resistance), e−2jβ1​Δ must be real, so

2β1​Δ=mπ

Using β1​=2π/λ1​ gives the requirement

Δ=m4λ1​​m=0,1,…

The needed impedance Z1​ is found by solving

±Z1​+Z2​Z2​−Z1​​=Z0​+Z1​Z0​−Z1​​

where + corresponds to m=0,2,… and − corresponds to m=1,3,… and

Expanding gives

±(−Z12​−Z0​Z1​+Z1​Z2​+Z0​Z2​)=Z0​Z2​+Z0​Z1​−Z1​Z2​−Z12​

For the + case, the solution is trivial: Z1​=Z0​, which corresponds to no intermediate region.

For the − case, corresponding to m=1,3,…,

Z1​=Z0​Z2​​

so that the impedance is the geometric mean of the load and source impedances.

In summary, given a fixed source and load impedance, a transmission line with a length that is an odd multiple of λ/4 and impedance that is the geometric mean of the source and load impedance can be placed between the source and the load to ensure no reflected wave in the source region.

Modify the program so that a wave of amplitude V−=1/2 is generated at the right boundary travels to the left. You are welcome to write re-write this program and your answer in another programming language.

Answer

The following program does the hand calculations. I did the Smith chart calculations in class.


            
clear

            
         

            
p = 3; % Problem number

            
         

            
if p == 1
    Zc = [1/2, 1/3]; % Characteristic impedances of segments
    w  = [1/4];      % Segment width(s)
elseif p == 2
    Zc = [1, 1/2];
    w  = [1/4];
else
    Zc = [1, 1/2, 1/3];
    w  = [1/4,1/8];
end

            
         

            
Z(length(Zc)) = Zc(end);

            
         

            
for n = [length(Zc):-1:2]
    r = Z(n)/Zc(n-1);
    R = exp(-4pi1iw(n-1))(r - 1)/(r + 1);
    Z(n-1) = Zc(n-1)*(1 + R)/(1 - R);
end

            
         

            
transpose(Z)

7 Final

Due Tuesday, December 15th at 11:59 pm.

In Section 5.2 (page 214) of the text and in class, the partial differential equations for V and I for a transmission line were derived using Maxwell’s equations and the assumption that the length scale of variations in V and I was much longer than the separation distance between the conducting plates or cylinder that formed the transmission line; see Figure 5.2 on page 215 for the case of conducting parallel plates. (The length scale assumption allowed us to assume that the fields had the same spatial dependence as a problem with a uniform current and charge distribution on the conductors.)

The partial differential equations derived from Maxwell’s equations were equivalent to the equations from a ladder circuit containing repeated ‘’differential’’ nodes (containing inductors and capacitors) of the form shown in Figure 5.2 on page 215.

Given the above, it seems reasonable to expect that a ladder circuit with enough ‘’discrete’’ nodes can approximate a continuous transmission line. Such a circuit is called an artificial transmission line.

In this problem, you will compute how V, I, and Z vary along an artificial transmission line and compare the results with the respective values for a continuous transmission line.

Partial Answer

In the time domain, the voltage across the inductor is

V1​(t)−V0​(t)=−LI1​˙​(t)

At node 1, KCL gives

I2​(t)=I1​(t)−IC​(t)

where IC​ is the current along the wire connected to the capacitor. Using QC​=CVC​, Q˙​C​=IC​=CV˙C​,

I2​(t)=I1​(t)−CV˙C​(t)

Steady state solutions to a system of linear first-order ODEs can be found efficiently (instead of using, say, the method of undetermined coefficients) by assuming solutions of the form

Vk​(t)=Re[Vk​ejωt]

Ik​(t)=Re[Ik​ejωt]

Using this and substation into V1​(t)−V0​(t)=−LI1​˙​(t) gives

Re[V1​ejωt−V0​ejωt+LI1​ejωt]=0

or

Re[ejωt(V1​−V0​+LI1​)]=0

In order for an equation of the form

Re[Cejωt]=0

to be true for all t, C=0. As a result, the relationship between the complex coefficients is

V1​−V0​=−LI1​

The other equations can be obtained using the same arguments used to arrive at this result.

Z1​ is found by adding the impedance of the load and inductor in series to get and equivalent impedance of ZL​+jωL. This impedance is in parallel with a capacitor, so the total equivalent impedance is

Z1​1​=ZC​1​+ZL​+jωL1​

where the impedance of the capacitor is 1/jωC. Substitution and re-writing gives

Z1​=jωC+ZL​+jωL1​1​

This impedance is in series with an inductor, so

Z0​=Z1​+jωL

One could also arrive at the equation for Z0​ by solving the four equations from the previous part for V0​/I1​.

As in the problems for transmission lines, we find the impedance at the source by working from the source to the load (or a region transition). Then, the voltages and currents are found by working from the source towards the load. The impedance was found in the previous problem. We can plug I1​=V0​/Z0​

into the equation

V1​=V0​−jωLI1​

and solve for V1​ in terms of V0​. Then, we can use

I2​=I1​−jωCV1​

to find I2​ in terms of V0​. Finally,

V2​=ZL​I2​

The answers can be verified by

  1. Using limits - do your equations give the expected results when ω→0 or ω→∞? What about similar limits for L and C?

  2. Solving the 4x4 system of equations manually

  3. Using a program such as Wolfram Alpha to solve the system of equations. MATLAB also has this capability with its Symbolic Math Toolkit.

  4. Find a circuit simulation program and choose arbitrary values of the parameters and verify that the amplitudes and phases from the simulation match your calculations. You can find simple programs that work online [https://www.falstad.com/circuit/] [https://www.circuitlab.com/] and do not require a license or software installation. See also [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_free_electronics_circuit_simulators] [https://www.electronics-lab.com/top-ten-online-circuit-simulators/]

  5. Use something like MATLAB’s Simulink or PSpice. There are many other options.

Zk−1​=Zk​+jωL1​+jωC1​

The equations

V1​=V0​−jωLI1​

I2​=I1​−jωCV1​

generalize to

k-j\omega L\widetilde{I}{k+1}__" class="katex-display fleqn">Vk+1​=V<emtype="md"marker=""​>k−jωLI</em>k+1

Ik+1​=Ik​−jωCVk​

The above equations were used in the program. In the program, I compare a plot of Zk​ and Vk​/Ik​ as they should be identical.

The procedure of solution is to start with k=0 and solve the first equation. Then A. use the second equation with k=1 to get I2​ and B. substitute this into the first equation when k=1 to get V2​. Steps A. and B. are then repeated for k=2,….

The problem statement asks for the answer in a different form. The two generalized equations above can be re-written as

k(1-\omega^2LC)-j\omega L\widetilde{I}{k}__" class="katex-display fleqn">Vk+1​=V<emtype="md"marker=""​>k(1−ω2LC)−jωLI</em>k

k(1+\omega^2LC)-j\omega C\widetilde{V}{k+1}__" class="katex-display fleqn">Ik+1​=I<emtype="md"marker=""​>k(1+ω2LC)−jωCV</em>k+1

Or, the indexing can be adjusted by subtracting 1 from the {k}_" class="katex">I<emtype="md"marker=""​>k index. (In the diagram, there would be currents I</em>0 and {1}_" class="katex">I<emtype="md"marker=""​>1 instead of I</em>1 and I2​.) Then,

k-j\omega L\widetilde{I}{k}__" class="katex-display fleqn">Vk+1​=V<emtype="md"marker=""​>k−jωLI</em>k

k-j\omega C\widetilde{V}{k+1}__" class="katex-display fleqn">Ik+1​=I<emtype="md"marker=""​>k−jωCV</em>k+1

Ideally the justification of 1. and 2. were done by plotting the continuous solution’s impedance, Vk​, and Vk​(t) which is hinted at given the questions asked earlier. In the case of 1., an animation of Vk​(t) will show a rightward traveling wave. In the case of 2., and animation of Vk​(t) will show a waveform that looks like the solution studied in previous HWs when there is a reflection. The standing wave ratio could be computed for the discrete case and compared with the continuous case. One could look at the case where ZL​>L/C​ and ZL​<L/C​ and ask if the solutions match expectations. Most students looked at how the magnitudes changed with respect to the node number but did not consider how the phase changed (it changes approximately linearly; one can phase shift a signal with such a circuit). One could also look at how Zk​ depends on k for a case where ZL​=L/C​ and compare this to the spatially dependent impedance for the continuous case.

The continuous solution was derived in 5.2 of the textbook. A key assumption is that the wavelength is large. In the discrete case, the number of nodes per wavelength should be large so that there are many differential elements per wavelength. The wavelength is inversely proportional to ω and so smaller ω gives a larger number of nodes per wave. This can be justified with plots by showing how the difference between the continuous solution and the discrete solution depends on ω.

The code given in the solution can be built upon to do all that is suggested above. Note that the discrete case does not have an intrinsic length scale. The number of nodes per wavelength is not an independent parameter that can be set as one would do in a typical numerical solution.

In the top circuit at [https://www.mathcha.io/editor/XoxD9fqLS21Tw635VQierrkQgIZG9nPVSWP6Lr], the source varies according to V0​cosωt.

Use the methods of Section 4.3 (which starts on page 177) to show that

V1​=V0​−jωLI1​

I2​=I1​−jωCV1​

V2​=V1​−jωLI2​

I2​=ZL​V2​​

One can find all of the unknown values of I and V using the previous equations given only V0​=V0​. An alternative relationship can also be used:

I1​=Z0​V0​​

where Z0​ is the equivalent impedance of the entire circuit.

Defining Z1​ as the equivalent impedance of ZL​ and the capacitor connected to node 1 and the inductor between node 1 and 2, find Z1​ and then Z0​.

7.2 Part II

For this part, use V0​=1 V, L=1 H, C=1 F, ω=0.005 s−1, and N=1000.

  1. Plot Vk​(t) at t=0.

  2. Plot Vk​(t) at t=(2π/ω)/4.

Justify the following claims using plots that compare the discrete ladder circuit solution with the exact solution.

  1. When ZL​=L/C​, the ladder network solution is a discrete approximation to an infinitely long continuous transmission line with a characteristic impedance of L/C​*. (Note that the ladder network only gives a solution in a finite region near the source, similar to an FDTD simulation with a source on the left and a simulation domain with a constant μ and ϵ - the wave appears to continue to propagate past the right boundary. Here ZL​ is analogous to the right boundary in the FDTD simulation.)

  2. When ZL​=L/C​, the ladder network solution is a discrete approximation of the source region of a continuous transmission line that has a change in characteristic impedance.

  3. The discrete approximation to the continuous solution is better for small ω.

Turn in a discussion of your answer in a file named Final_Part_II.pdf and name your figures Final_Part_II_Figure_X.pdf, where X is an integer.

* If you are wondering how a circuit containing only inductive and capacitive elements can have a real impedance, see [https://www.feynmanlectures.caltech.edu/II_22.html Section 22-6 of the Feynman Lectures on Physics] - “In a circuit of this kind, energy is continually absorbed from the generator at a constant rate and flows constantly out into the network, supplying energy which is stored in the inductances and capacitances down the line.” In the limit of ω→0, z0​ in [https://www.feynmanlectures.caltech.edu/II_22.html equation 22.28] becomes L/C​.
